questions.text: Which one of the following parameters is most useful in determining the time required to reach steady-state plasma concentration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Half-life

Explanation: Time to reach steady-state is approximately 4–5 half-lives of the drug. This holds true for drugs following first-order kinetics.

choices.text: Drug is mostly confined to the plasma
Drug distributes widely in body tissues

questions.text: A 70 kg patient receives a drug with a volume of distribution (Vd) of 3 L/kg. Which statement is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Drug distributes widely in body tissues

Explanation: Vd = 3 L/kg × 70 = 210 L — this is much greater than total body water, indicating the drug is lipophilic and extensively distributed in tissues

choices.text: Have a shorter duration of action
Have a reduced volume of distribution
Be more freely filtered in the kidney

questions.text: A drug with high plasma protein binding will most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Have a reduced volume of distribution

Explanation: Protein-bound drugs stay in the vascular compartment, limiting their distribution to tissues → low Vd.

questions.text: Which enzyme family is most commonly involved in phase I metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CYP450

Explanation: Phase I reactions (oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis) are mostly mediated by CYP450 enzymes, notably CYP3A4.

choices.text: Drug B will have prolonged action
Drug B efficacy will be reduced

questions.text: Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B via CYP3A4 induction. What is the expected result?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Drug B efficacy will be reduced

Explanation: Enzyme induction = increased metabolism → lower drug levels, reduced efficacy of Drug B.

choices.text: A constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time
A constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

questions.text: A drug follows zero-order kinetics. Which statement is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

Explanation: In zero-order kinetics, the drug is eliminated at a constant amount per time (not fraction), regardless of concentration. This occurs when elimination pathways are saturated (e.g., phenytoin, ethanol, aspirin at high doses).

choices.text: Shift the curve to the right
Shift the curve to the left

questions.text: A competitive antagonist will have what effect on a drug’s dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shift the curve to the right

Explanation: Competitive antagonists increase the EC50 (require more drug to produce the same effect) but do not affect Emax. Hence, the dose-response curve shifts right.

questions.text: A neonate with sepsis is treated with chloramphenicol and later develops gray baby syndrome. What is the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Reduced glucuronidation

Explanation: Neonates have immature liver enzymes, leading to impaired glucuronidation, causing chloramphenicol toxicity → "gray baby syndrome."

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic pain is prescribed an adrenergic agonist for its analgesic effects. Which medication is most appropriate for this use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clonidine.

Here's why:

•	Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It decreases sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system and is well-known for its use in chronic pain management, particularly in conditions like neuropathic pain. It has analgesic properties due to its action at both spinal and supraspinal sites.

The other choices:

•	Methyldopa is primarily used as an antihypertensive, particularly in pregnancy. It doesn't have notable analgesic effects.

•	Epinephrine is a non-selective adrenergic agonist (stimulates alpha and beta receptors) and is mainly used for anaphylaxis, cardiac arrest, and sometimes to prolong the effects of local anesthetics — not primarily for pain management alone.

•	Isoproterenol is a non-selective beta agonist (beta-1 and beta-2), used mainly for bradycardia or heart block. It doesn't have analgesic properties.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and is given a medication to manage hypertension and symptoms related to excess catecholamines. Which drug works by inhibiting the synthesis of norepinephrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metyrosine

Explanation: Metyrosine inhibits the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase, which is crucial for the synthesis of norepinephrine. Reserpine affects storage, clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist, and alpha-methyl-p-tyrosine is similar to metyrosine in its action but is less commonly used.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery requires sedation but should remain arousable during the procedure. Which medication is particularly useful for this purpose due to its sedative and analgesic properties without significant respiratory depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Dexmedetomidine.

Here's the breakdown:

•	Dexmedetomidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist (like clonidine but more selective and potent) that provides sedation, analgesia, and anxiolysis without causing significant respiratory depression. Importantly, patients sedated with dexmedetomidine are easily arousable, making it ideal for procedures where you need sedation but also need the patient to respond if necessary.

The other options:

•	Propofol is a powerful sedative-hypnotic used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It causes deep sedation and significant respiratory depression — patients are usually not easily arousable under its effect.

•	Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that also causes sedation and amnesia but can cause respiratory depression and makes patients less responsive.

•	Fentanyl is a potent opioid analgesic; while it has sedative properties, it also carries a high risk of respiratory depression and is mainly used for pain management rather than light sedation alone.

questions.text: 68-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 3B is being treated for hypertension. Which of the following beta-blockers should be used with caution due to its significant renal excretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atenolol

Explanation: Atenolol is primarily excreted by the kidneys, so dosage adjustments are necessary in patients with renal impairment. Carvedilol and nebivolol are metabolized by the liver, and metoprolol has renal and hepatic metabolism, but atenolol requires careful monitoring in CKD patients

questions.text: A patient with beta-blocker poisoning shows severe hypotension unresponsive to intravenous fluids and atropine. Which of the following agents can be used ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glucagon

Explanation: Glucagon is used in beta-blocker poisoning because it directly increases cAMP levels in cardiac cells, which helps overcome the effects of beta-blocker-induced cardiac depression and improves cardiac output and blood pressure. Calcium gluconate is used for calcium channel blocker overdose, flumazenil is used for benzodiazepine overdose, and naloxone is for opioid overdose

questions.text: Which of the following drugs inhibits the high-affinity choline transporter at the presynaptic terminal of cholinergic neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hemicholinium-3

Explanation: Hemicholinium-3 blocks the high-affinity choline transporter (CHT1), reducing choline reuptake and thus decreasing ACh synthesis.

•	Vesamicol blocks VAChT (storage of ACh).

•	Botulinum toxin prevents ACh release, not uptake.

•	Physostigmine inhibits AChE, increasing ACh levels, not decreasing synthesis.

choices.text: Treating dry mouth in Sjögren's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common clinical use of cholinergic agonists?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: Cholinergic agonists are not typically used for managing Parkinson’s disease. Instead, Parkinson’s disease is treated with dopaminergic agents and other drugs, not cholinergic agonists. The other options are valid clinical uses of cholinergic agonists.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a monoclonal antibody that targets the neonatal Fc receptor to reduce circulating autoantibodies in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the neonatal Fc receptor to reduce circulating autoantibodies and is used in treating generalized myasthenia gravis in patients who are refractory to other treatments

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an anticholinergic agent used to treat overactive bladder by reducing bladder contractions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Oxybutynin

Explanation: Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic medication used to manage overactive bladder by decreasing bladder contractions and reducing urinary urgency and frequency.

questions.text: Which antianginal drug should be avoided in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nitrates

Explanation: Nitrates can worsen obstruction in HOCM by reducing preload, increasing the outflow tract gradient. β-blockers and non-dihydropyridine CCBs are preferred.

questions.text: Which antianginal drug is associated with an increased risk of bradyarrhythmia and visual disturbances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Ivabradine

Explanation: Ivabradine inhibits the If current, reducing heart rate. It can cause bradycardia and luminous phenomena (phosphenes).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with ventricular tachycardia (VT) 48 hours after an anterior STEMI. He is hemodynamically stable. Which drug is the most appropriate for acute VT termination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Amiodarone

Concept: Post-MI, VT is often reentry-mediated, and amiodarone (Class III) is preferred due to its potassium channel blockade and low proarrhythmic risk. Flecainide (Class IC) is contraindicated post-MI due to increased mortality (CAST trial).

questions.text: Which of the following novel agents acts by stimulating soluble guanylate cyclase and is approved for HFrEF to reduce the risk of CV death and hospitalization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vericiguat

Vericiguat is a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator, enhancing the NO–cGMP pathway, improving myocardial relaxation and vascular tone. It is approved for HFrEF patients with recent decompensation (VICTORIA trial). Omecamtiv mecarbil is a myosin activator; Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor, and Ivabradine slows HR via the If channel.

questions.text: Which class of drugs improves both symptoms and survival in HFrEF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

SGLT2 inhibitors

Concept: SGLT2 inhibitors (Empagliflozin, Dapagliflozin) reduce hospitalization and mortality in HFrEF patients, independent of diabetes status.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old pregnant woman (28 weeks gestation) presents with BP 170/110 mmHg.

Which drug is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Losartan

Concept: ACE inhibitors (Enalapril) & ARBs (Losartan) are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic effects (renal dysplasia, fetal death).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male on Amlodipine, Lisinopril, and Hydrochlorothiazide still has BP 160/95 mmHg. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Add Spironolactone

Concept: Spironolactone is the most effective add-on therapy for resistant hypertension (PATHWAY-2 trial).

questions.text: Which antihypertensive drug is most commonly associated with drug-induced lupus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hydralazine

Concept: Hydralazine and Procainamide are most commonly linked to drug-induced lupus (Anti-histone Abs positive).

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the drug and its mechanism in pulmonary arterial hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Macitentan – Endothelin receptor antagonist

Explanation:

•	Macitentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist (ERA) approved for PAH.

•	Ambrisentan is also an ERA (selective ETA).

•	Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor, not a guanylate cyclase stimulator.

Riociguat is a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator, not an ERA.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants acts by indirectly inhibiting Factor Xa through antithrombin III activation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fondaparinux

Fondaparinux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that binds to antithrombin III, enhancing its activity to inhibit Factor Xa.

•	Rivaroxaban is a direct Xa inhibitor.

•	Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor.

•	Bivalirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor used in PCI.

choices.text: Protein C and S deficiency exacerbated by warfarin

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female with a history of deep vein thrombosis started on warfarin presents with painful purplish skin lesions on her thighs. 
What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Protein C and S deficiency exacerbated by warfarin.

Explanation: Warfarin initially reduces protein C and S levels, leading to a transient hypercoagulable state that can cause skin necrosis, especially in patients with an underlying deficiency. Bridging with heparin prevents this complication.

questions.text: Which of the following antiplatelet drugs exerts its effect by irreversible inhibition of ADP (P2Y12) receptors on platelets?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clopidogrel

Explanation:

Clopidogrel irreversibly blocks the P2Y12 receptor, preventing ADP-mediated platelet activation and aggregation.

•	Cangrelor = irreversible P2Y12 blocker.

•	Abciximab blocks GPIIb/IIIa receptors.

•	Cilostazol is a PDE3 inhibitor, increasing cAMP.

questions.text: Which of the following Anticoagulants That Require Monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Warfarin, UFH, Argatroban, Bivalirudin ➔ Need routine monitoring.

LMWH, DOACs (Dabigatran, Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, Edoxaban) ➔ No routine monitoring.

Enoxaparin ➔ Special cases only (pregnant, renal failure).

questions.text: Which fibrinolytic agent has the longest half-life and can be given as a single IV bolus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tenecteplase

Explanation:

•	Tenecteplase has the longest half-life (~22 minutes) and is given as a single IV bolus.

•	Reteplase requires two boluses.

•	Alteplase requires infusion over 60 minutes.

•	Streptokinase requires prolonged infusion (30–60 min)

choices.text: Streptokinase can be reversed by Protamine
Heparin toxicity is treated with Vitamin K
Warfarin-induced bleeding can be reversed with Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)
Rivaroxaban toxicity is treated with Idarucizumab

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding antidotes to anticoagulants and thrombolytics is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Warfarin-induced bleeding can be reversed with Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)

Explanation:

Warfarin inhibits synthesis of Vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. In bleeding patients, FFP or Prothrombin Complex Concentrates (PCC) are 
used for immediate reversal, along with Vitamin K for delayed action.

•	Streptokinase has no specific antidote.

•	Heparin is reversed by Protamine sulfate.

•	Rivaroxaban is reversed by Andexanet alfa.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of Alirocumab in lowering LDL cholesterol levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Monoclonal antibody against PCSK9

Explanation:

Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor, a monoclonal antibody that binds PCSK9 and prevents it from degrading LDL receptors. This increases LDL receptor availability on hepatocytes, enhancing LDL clearance.

•    HMG-CoA reductase is inhibited by statins.

•    Ezetimibe blocks intestinal absorption.

Fibrates activate PPAR-α.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main gastrointestinal adverse effect associated with bile acid sequestrants like cholestyramine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Constipation and bloating

Explanation:

Bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine, colestipol) bind bile acids in the intestine, preventing reabsorption and increasing cholesterol catabolism.

Common GI side effects:

•	Constipation, bloating, and flatulence

•	May impair absorption of fat-soluble vitamins and certain drugs like warfarin, digoxin

choices.text: Niacin, by taking aspirin before dosing

questions.text: Which lipid-lowering agent can cause severe flushing, and how can it be minimized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Niacin, by taking aspirin before dosing

Explanation:

•	Niacin (vitamin B3) causes prostaglandin-mediated flushing.

•	Aspirin (325 mg) taken 30 minutes before niacin reduces flushing.

•	Statins do not cause flushing, and their myopathy risk is reduced when taken at night.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics is used in the treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acetazolamide

Explanation:

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, reduces CSF production and is the drug of choice in idiopathic intracranial hypertension.
It is also used in glaucoma, epilepsy, and acute mountain sickness — all non-renal indications.
Furosemide and thiazides are not effective in reducing CSF production

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics has been shown to reduce calcium stone formation in patients with idiopathic hypercalciuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hydrochlorothiazide

Thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide enhance calcium reabsorption in the DCT, reducing urinary calcium and preventing recurrent calcium kidney stones — a non-renal indication.

Loop diuretics increase urinary calcium and may worsen stone risk.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations increases the risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Spironolactone + ACE inhibitor

Both Spironolactone (a potassium-sparing diuretic) and ACE inhibitors decrease aldosterone effect, leading to reduced K⁺ excretion and hyperkalemia.

This combination must be used cautiously, especially in renal insufficiency.

The other combinations do not pose a significant risk of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is started on a drug to slow disease progression. Which of the following is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tolvaptan

Explanation:

•	Tolvaptan, a V2 receptor antagonist, slows cyst growth and disease progression in ADPKD by reducing cAMP-mediated fluid accumulation in renal cysts.

Vasopressin (via V2 receptors) promotes cyst growth by increasing cAMP levels

questions.text: Which proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is known to have a significant interaction with clopidogrel, potentially reducing its effectiveness and increasing the risk of cardiovascular events?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Omeprazole

Explanation: Omeprazole is a PPI that inhibits CYP2C19, an enzyme necessary for the activation of clopidogrel. This interaction can reduce the efficacy of clopidogrel, increasing the risk of cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in IBS-C acts by stimulating guanylate cyclase-C (GC-C), leading to increased intestinal secretion and motility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Linaclotide

Linaclotide and plecanatide are guanylate cyclase-C agonists. They ↑ cGMP, promoting chloride and bicarbonate secretion via CFTR → ↑ fluid secretion & motility.

•    Lubiprostone: Activates ClC-2 channels

•    Tenapanor: Inhibits NHE3 (Na+/H+ exchanger)

•    Loperamide: μ-opioid agonist, used for IBS-D

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective α4β7 integrin antagonist used in the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vedolizumab

Vedolizumab is an anti-α4β7 integrin monoclonal antibody, blocking lymphocyte migration specifically to the GI tract, thus reducing gut inflammation in IBD.

•	It has a gut-selective action, unlike natalizumab which also affects the CNS.

Used in moderate-to-severe IBD not responding to anti-TNFs.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a known adverse effect of montelukast?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bradycardia

Montelukast can cause:

•	Neuropsychiatric effects (agitation, aggression, nightmares)

•	Rarely associated with Churg-Strauss syndrome

•	Mild hepatotoxicity (more with zafirlukast)

Bradycardia is not typical.

questions.text:
Regarding theophylline true statements are

A. causes adverse effects when plasma level >10mg/L

B. causes diuresis (due to inhibition of adenosine A1 receptors

C. theophylline is more cardiotoxic than Ipratropium bromide

D. Adding Erythromycin with theophylline will decrease the adverse effects of theophylline
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Unwanted effects of theophylline are usually related to plasma concentration and tend to occur at Cp greater than 15 mg/L.

Theophylline causes adverse effects of diuresis (due to inhibition of adenosine A1 receptors)

Theophylline is more cardio toxic and can cause both tachycardia and ventricular arrhythmias

Theophylline is metabolized in the liver, mainly by CYP1A2

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody used in asthma treatment targets interleukin-4 (IL-4) and interleukin-13 (IL-13), and is used for severe asthma with an eosinophilic phenotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dupilumab

Explanation: Dupilumab targets IL-4 and IL-13, which are key cytokines in the inflammatory process of asthma. It is used for severe asthma with an eosinophilic phenotype or other persistent asthma symptoms.

choices.text: It is a competitive agonist at the benzodiazepine binding site
It can be safely used in all cases of benzodiazepine overdose
It is used for the reversal of benzodiazepine effects in diagnostic and therapeutic procedures
It has a long half-life and does not require repeat dosing

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding Flumazenil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is used for the reversal of benzodiazepine effects in diagnostic and therapeutic procedures

Explanation:

•	Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist, not an agonist (Option A is incorrect).

•	It is not safe in all cases; in patients with chronic benzodiazepine use, it may precipitate withdrawal symptoms and seizures (Option B is incorrect).

•	It has a short half-life (~1 hour) and may require repeat dosing to prevent sedation relapse (Option D is incorrect).

•	Flumazenil is mainly used to reverse benzodiazepine effects in medical settings like procedural sedation or suspected overdose (Option C is correct).

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with chronic insomnia has failed multiple benzodiazepines and Z-drugs. Which drug is an alternative?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suvorexant

Explanation: Suvorexant is an orexin receptor antagonist used in refractory insomnia

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with absence seizures is started on an appropriate first-line drug. He later develops lethargy, weight loss, and kidney stones. Which drug is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Topiramate

Explanation:

Topiramate is a broad-spectrum AED used in absence seizures and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. It causes weight loss, sedation, and nephrolithiasis due to carbonic anhydrase inhibition.

•	Valproate: weight gain, hepatotoxicity

•	Ethosuximide: GI upset, used only in absence

•	Clobazam: Sedation, used in LGS

questions.text: Which of the following newer antiepileptic drugs acts by binding to synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A) to inhibit neurotransmitter release?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Brivaracetam

Explanation:

Brivaracetam (like levetiracetam) targets SV2A, reducing glutamate release. It is used in focal seizures and has fewer behavioral adverse effects than levetiracetam.

•	Lacosamide: enhances slow Na⁺ inactivation

•	Rufinamide: prolongs Na⁺ channel inactivation

•	Perampanel: noncompetitive AMPA receptor antagonist

questions.text: Which of the following combinations is correctly matched with the clinical indication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Levetiracetam – Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

Levetiracetam is effective in generalized seizures, especially juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME).

•	Rufinamide is used in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

•	Carbamazepine can worsen absence seizures.

•	Ethosuximide is effective only in pure absence seizures.

questions.text: A Parkinson’s patient has sudden, unpredictable "off" episodes despite optimal levodopa therapy. What is the best rescue treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Apomorphine

Explanation: Apomorphine (dopamine agonist) provides rapid relief of off-episodes

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with Parkinson’s disease for 8 years presents with visual hallucinations and paranoid delusions, believing that his family members are impostors. He has no history of dementia and is on carbidopa-levodopa and pramipexole for symptom control. Examination shows tremor, bradykinesia, and mild postural instability, but no significant cognitive impairment. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his psychosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pimavanserin

Parkinson’s disease psychosis (PDP) occurs due to dopaminergic therapy and disease progression. Pimavanserin, a selective serotonin 5-HT₂A inverse agonist, is the only FDA-approved drug for Parkinson’s psychosis and does not worsen motor symptoms.

Key Points:
•	Haloperidol worsens Parkinsonian symptoms (dopamine blockade). ❌
•	Clozapine is effective but requires frequent monitoring due to agranulocytosis risk. ⚠️
•	Quetiapine is sometimes used, but pimavanserin is preferred due to better safety.

Pimavanserin is the first-line treatment for Parkinson’s disease psychosis.

questions.text: Which of the following drug useful to control levodopa induced dyskinesia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Amantadine

Levodopa-induced dyskinesia (LID) is a common complication in patients with Parkinson’s disease (PD) undergoing long-term levodopa therapy. Amantadine is the only drug among the options provided that has proven efficacy in reducing LID.

Why is Amantadine the Correct Choice?

Amantadine is a weak NMDA receptor antagonist and has dopaminergic properties. It is believed to exert its anti-dyskinetic effect by:

•   Blocking NMDA receptors, thereby reducing glutamatergic excitotoxicity, which is implicated in dyskinesia.

•   Increasing dopamine release and reuptake inhibition, helping smooth out motor fluctuations.

•   Reducing the "on" phase dyskinesia seen with levodopa therapy.

Clinical Evidence:

•	Amantadine has been clinically proven to reduce the severity and duration of LID.

•	It has both immediate-release (IR) and extended-release (ER) formulations, with ER formulations providing more stable symptom control.

•	A sudden withdrawal of amantadine can worsen dyskinesia, so it must be tapered gradually.

Why are the Other Options Incorrect?

B) Entacapone (COMT Inhibitor)

•	Entacapone prolongs the half-life of levodopa by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT).

•	It does not reduce dyskinesia; instead, it may worsen it by increasing overall dopaminergic stimulation.

C) Selegiline (MAO-B Inhibitor)

•	Selegiline prevents dopamine breakdown by inhibiting monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B).

•	It may prolong levodopa’s effect but does not significantly control dyskinesia.

•	In fact, increased dopamine levels may exacerbate dyskinesia in some cases.

D) Istradefylline (Adenosine A2A Receptor Antagonist)

•	Istradefylline is used as an adjunct to reduce "off" time in PD patients.

•	It does not directly treat dyskinesia but helps improve motor function.

•	Some studies suggest it may worsen dyskinesia as it modulates indirect basal ganglia pathways.

questions.text: What is the therapeutic serum level of lithium for maintenance therapy in bipolar disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

0.4 – 0.8 mEq/L

For maintenance, lithium levels are ideally maintained at 0.6–0.8 mEq/L.

For acute mania, slightly higher levels (0.8–1.2 mEq/L) are targeted.

Toxicity risk increases significantly beyond 1.5 mEq/L.

questions.text: Which drug is preferred in bipolar depression due to its efficacy in the depressive phase without triggering mania?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Lamotrigine

Lamotrigine is particularly effective in the depressive phase of bipolar disorder and has low risk of switching to mania.

•	Valproate is used in mania and prophylaxis

Risperidone and haloperidol are antipsychotics used in mania

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with seizures, wide QRS complex on ECG, and anticholinergic signs (dry mouth, mydriasis) after an overdose. Which antidepressant class is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

TCA

Explanation:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) in overdose cause:

•	Anticholinergic toxicity: dry mouth, urinary retention, tachycardia

•	Cardiotoxicity: wide QRS, arrhythmias

Seizures

Management: IV sodium bicarbonate for QRS widening and arrhythmias

questions.text: Which newer oral antidepressant approved for postpartum depression is also a GABA-A receptor modulator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Zuranolone

Explanation:

Zuranolone is an oral neurosteroid, structurally related to brexanolone, acting on GABA-A receptors.

•	It is used for short-term treatment of postpartum depression. Unlike brexanolone, it is orally administered.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a partial opioid agonist used in opioid deaddiction programs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Buprenorphine

Explanation:

Buprenorphine is a partial μ-opioid receptor agonist and κ-antagonist, used in maintenance therapy for opioid dependence.

•	It has a ceiling effect for respiratory depression.

•	Often combined with naloxone (suboxone) to prevent misuse.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for long-term abstinence in alcohol deaddiction by blocking the euphoric effects of alcohol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Naltrexone

Explanation:

Naltrexone is a μ-opioid receptor antagonist that reduces craving and relapse by blocking reward pathways.

•	Disulfiram: causes aversive reaction by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase.

Acamprosate: modulates glutamate/GABA, reduces cravings.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs is contraindicated in patients with heart failure due to the risk of fluid retention and exacerbation of HF symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pioglitazone

Explanation:

Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione (TZD), activates PPAR-γ, improving insulin sensitivity but causing fluid retention, weight gain, and risk of worsening heart failure.

Classically avoided in NYHA class III–IV HF.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs primarily increases insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Glipizide

Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin release from pancreatic beta cells.

questions.text: What is the primary drug therapy for Nelson’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cabergoline

Explanation: Nelson's syndrome involves ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors after adrenalectomy. Cabergoline, a dopamine agonist, can reduce ACTH secretion from the tumor.

Drug Therapies in Nelson’s Syndrome

Cabergoline (Dopamine Agonist) – First-line Option

•	Mechanism: Acts on D2 dopamine receptors in corticotroph tumors to suppress ACTH secretion.

•	Use: Often used first due to oral availability, safety, and tolerability.

Octreotide (Somatostatin Analog)

•	Mechanism: Binds somatostatin receptor subtype 2 (SSTR2) on pituitary tumors.

•	Use: Variable efficacy in Nelson’s—some patients show decreased ACTH levels and tumor stabilization, but not all respond.

•	Limitation: Corticotroph tumors express low SSTR2, so octreotide may not always be effective.

Pasireotide (Newer Somatostatin Analog)

•	Mechanism: Has high affinity for SSTR5, which is more commonly expressed on ACTH-secreting tumors.

•	Use: More effective than octreotide in reducing ACTH and tumor size in Nelson’s syndrome.

•	Downside: Can cause hyperglycemia as a side effect due to insulin suppression.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of gepotidacin?

Inhibits bacterial DNA replication enzymes

By inhibiting these enzymes, it prevents the bacteria from replicating their DNA, leading to bacterial death. This mechanism is distinct from other antibiotic classes, contributing to its effectiveness against resistant strains

questions.text: Which of the following drug is useful in cytokine storm in COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tocilizumab

1. Cytokine Storm in COVID-19:

•	A cytokine storm is an exaggerated immune response characterized by excessive release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including IL-6, which contributes to severe systemic inflammation, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and multi-organ failure in COVID-19.

•	IL-6 inhibitors are effective in managing cytokine storms by targeting and neutralizing this critical inflammatory pathway.

2. Role of Tocilizumab:

•	Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that blocks the IL-6 receptor, reducing the inflammatory response associated with the cytokine storm.

•	It has been widely used in patients with severe or critical COVID-19, particularly those with elevated IL-6 levels and requiring oxygen or mechanical ventilation.

3. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

•	A) Secukinumab:

o	Targets IL-17.

o	Approved for autoimmune diseases like psoriatic arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis.

o	Does not play a significant role in cytokine storms, as IL-17 is not the primary cytokine involved in COVID-19 pathology.

•	B) Sarilumab:

o	Like tocilizumab, sarilumab is also an IL-6 receptor inhibitor.

o	It can be used in cytokine storms but is less commonly employed compared to tocilizumab due to its limited availability during the pandemic.

•	D) Ustekinumab:

o	Targets IL-12 and IL-23.

o	Used in conditions like psoriatic arthritis and Crohn's disease but has no role in managing cytokine storms in COVID-19.

choices.text: Selective blockade of NaV1.8 sodium channels in peripheral nerves

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of Suzetrigine (Journavx), the first non-opioid pain medication approved in over two decades?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Selective blockade of NaV1.8 sodium channels in peripheral nerves

Suzetrigine is a first-in-class non-opioid analgesic that selectively inhibits the NaV1.8 sodium channels located in peripheral nerves. By targeting these channels, Suzetrigine effectively reduces pain transmission without affecting central nervous system pathways, thereby minimizing the risk of addiction and other opioid-related side effects. It was approved by the FDA in January 2025 for the treatment of moderate to severe acute pain

questions.text: FDA approved drug to treat neurogenic orthostatic hypotension are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Midodrine 

•	Mechanism: Midodrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic agonist that causes vasoconstriction, thereby increasing blood pressure.

•	Usage: It is often used as a first-line treatment for neurogenic orthostatic hypotension. Fludrocortisone 

•	Mechanism: Fludrocortisone is a mineralocorticoid that increases sodium and water reabsorption in the kidneys, which helps increase blood volume and blood pressure.

•	Usage: It is used as an adjunct to other treatments to manage symptoms of neurogenic orthostatic hypotension.

Droxidopa 

•	Mechanism: Droxidopa is a prodrug that converts to norepinephrine in the body, thereby increasing blood pressure and improving symptoms of orthostatic hypotension.

•	Usage: Specifically approved for the treatment of symptomatic neurogenic orthostatic hypotension.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder is being treated with fluoxetine. She presents to the emergency department with agitation, confusion, tremors, and a temperature of 38.9°C (102°F). Her heart rate is 115 bpm, and she has hyperreflexia and clonus on neurological exam. Upon further questioning, she reveals that she recently began taking tramadol for a back injury. which of the following drug useful in treating these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cyproheptadine

Explanation of Options:

•	A. Dantrolene
Used in malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), not serotonin syndrome.

•	B. Cyproheptadine
First-line antidote for serotonin syndrome. It is a 5-HT2A receptor antagonist and effectively reverses the 
serotonergic toxicity.

•	C. Propranolol
Not appropriate in serotonin syndrome. Non-selective beta-blockers can worsen hypotension or mask compensatory tachycardia. They may even be harmful in severe cases.

•	D. Naltrexone
An opioid receptor antagonist used in opioid/alcohol use disorders, but has no role in serotonin syndrome.

Tecovirimat
